vsp

Source: vignettes/vsp.Rmd
vsp.Rmd

Obtaining estimates from vsp is straightforward. We recommend representing networks as igraph objects or (sparse) Matrix objects from the Matrix package (see also ?Matrix).

Once you have your network in one of these formats, you can get estimates by calling the vsp() function. The result is an object of class "vsp_fa".

library(vsp)
library(Matrix)

# create a random sparse adjacency matrix
M <- sign(rsparsematrix(12, 12, nnz = 40))^2

# vintage sparse pca
fa <- vsp(M, rank = 5, scale = TRUE, center = TRUE, recenter = TRUE)
fa
#> Vintage Sparse PCA Factor Analysis
#> 
#> Rows (n):   12
#> Cols (d):   12
#> Factors (rank): 5
#> Lambda[rank]:   0.113
#> 
#> Pre-Processing Options (TODO) 
#> 
#> Components
#> 
#> Z: 12 x 5 [dgeMatrix] 
#> B: 5 x 5 [dgeMatrix] 
#> Y: 12 x 5 [dgeMatrix] 
#> u: 12 x 5 [matrix] 
#> d: 5      [numeric] 
#> v: 12 x 5 [matrix]

Here we demonstrate vsp usage on an igraph object, using the enron network from igraphdata package to demonstrate this functionality. First we peak at the graph:

library(igraph)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'igraph'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     decompose, spectrum
#> The following object is masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     union
data(enron, package = "igraphdata")

enron
#> IGRAPH 64ec693 D--- 184 125409 -- Enron email network
#> + attr: LDC_names (g/c), LDC_desc (g/c), name (g/c), Citation (g/c),
#> | Email (v/c), Name (v/c), Note (v/c), Time (e/c), Reciptype (e/c),
#> | Topic (e/n), LDC_topic (e/n)
#> + edges from 64ec693:
#>  [1]  25->154  25->154  30-> 30  30-> 30  30-> 30  30-> 30  39-> 39  52-> 67
#>  [9]  52-> 67  52-> 67  52-> 67  61->100  61->100  61->163  61->163  61->166
#> [17]  61->166  61->170  64-> 59  64-> 59  64-> 64  64-> 64  64->147  64->147
#> [25]  64->164  64->164  64->168  66-> 66  66-> 66  67->129  67->129  67->129
#> [33]  67->129  93-> 10  93-> 10  93-> 10  93-> 10  93-> 39  93-> 39  93-> 93
#> [41]  93-> 93  93-> 93  93-> 93  93->124  93->124 100-> 61 100-> 61 115->115
#> + ... omitted several edges

Now we estimate:

library(Matrix)

enron_fa <- vsp(enron, rank = 30)
enron_fa
#> Vintage Sparse PCA Factor Analysis
#> 
#> Rows (n):   184
#> Cols (d):   184
#> Factors (rank): 30
#> Lambda[rank]:   306.8711
#> 
#> Pre-Processing Options (TODO) 
#> 
#> Components
#> 
#> Z: 184 x 30 [dgeMatrix] 
#> B: 30 x 30 [dgeMatrix] 
#> Y: 184 x 30 [dgeMatrix] 
#> u: 184 x 30 [matrix] 
#> d: 30      [numeric] 
#> v: 184 x 30 [matrix]

The default print method has a large amount of valuable information. First, we learn that the graph has 184 nodes, and that we have used rank = 30 as our guess of the rank of A, the network adjacency matrix. The 30th singular value of A is 0.2039. This is of interest, as we expect lambda[k] ~ 0 to indicate that we have we have overestimated the rank of A, in say, blockmodels.

The pre-processing section indicates that the matrix representation of the graph was not row- and column-centered before estimation (center = FALSE), and that we used the graph Laplacian rather than the adjacency matrix (normalize = TRUE).

By default, normalize = TRUE not only uses the graph Laplacian, but also regularizes the graph Laplacian using mean in-degree and out-degree. See [1] for details on how we form the regularized graph Laplacian.

In general, you do not need to tune tau_row and tau_col. To turn off regularization (not recommended!), see tau_row = 0 and tau_col = 0. This often leads to eigenvector localization and thus overfitting.

vsp(M, rank = 5, tau_row = 0, tau_col = 0)
#> Vintage Sparse PCA Factor Analysis
#> 
#> Rows (n):   12
#> Cols (d):   12
#> Factors (rank): 5
#> Lambda[rank]:   1.5672
#> 
#> Pre-Processing Options (TODO) 
#> 
#> Components
#> 
#> Z: 12 x 5 [dgeMatrix] 
#> B: 5 x 5 [dgeMatrix] 
#> Y: 12 x 5 [dgeMatrix] 
#> u: 12 x 5 [matrix] 
#> d: 5      [numeric] 
#> v: 12 x 5 [matrix]

The components U, d, and V are the standard elements of the singular value decomposition of your network.

At the moment, we are performing centering explicitly, which is inefficient and converts adjacency matrices from sparse into dense matrices. Setting center = TRUE produces a warning to remind you of this. We plan to implement implicit centering shortly.

vsp(M, rank = 5, center = TRUE)
#> Vintage Sparse PCA Factor Analysis
#> 
#> Rows (n):   12
#> Cols (d):   12
#> Factors (rank): 5
#> Lambda[rank]:   1.519
#> 
#> Pre-Processing Options (TODO) 
#> 
#> Components
#> 
#> Z: 12 x 5 [dgeMatrix] 
#> B: 5 x 5 [dgeMatrix] 
#> Y: 12 x 5 [dgeMatrix] 
#> u: 12 x 5 [matrix] 
#> d: 5      [numeric] 
#> v: 12 x 5 [matrix]

You can approximately reconstruct the matrix representation of your network as follows:

fa2 <- vsp(M, rank = 5, normalize = FALSE)

fa2$u %*% diag(fa2$d) %*% t(fa2$v)
#>             col01        col02       col03         col04       col05
#> row01  0.44903214 -0.107853306  0.13197642 -0.0953282389  0.83876500
#> row02 -0.23762628 -0.004892146  0.83962402  0.0335138985  0.12085849
#> row03 -0.17976949  1.043876192  0.32608464  0.2192719832 -0.11797458
#> row04  0.75256701 -0.121121625  1.08442731 -0.2559784659  0.26555808

In the example above, this will not approximate M, but rather the regularized graph Laplacian formed from M. Similarly, the varimax-rotated network approximate reconstruction is

fa$Z %*% fa$B %*% t(fa$Y)
#> 12 x 12 Matrix of class "dgeMatrix"
#>           col01     col02     col03     col04     col05     col06     col07
#> row01 0.3626349 0.3685737 0.4889053 0.2395072 0.4547848 0.4184406 0.2627740
#> row02 0.3293882 0.4112074 0.5682507 0.2775004 0.4384382 0.4509832 0.3951748
#> row03 0.2931440 0.4530405 0.5172771 0.2680881 0.4009199 0.3879035 0.2843592
#> row04 0.4448575 0.4819843 0.6518902 0.3196051 0.5443695 0.5483496 0.3960547
#> row05 0.2766927 0.3726490 0.4780891 0.2382100 0.4328331 0.3714717 0.2889701
#> row06 0.3463559 0.4602700 0.5718340 0.2882801 0.4727084 0.4507448 0.3346975
#> row07 0.3785166 0.5205481 0.6405201 0.3330413 0.5607402 0.5436619 0.3589563
#> row08 0.1760412 0.3600172 0.3802566 0.2143533 0.3045147 0.3156372 0.1910094

#> row12 0.6072293 0.4538744 0.3553245 0.4082886 0.3867618

In general, you won’t want to explicit reconstruct the network matrix for large networks since the reconstruction will be dense.

If you want to directly manipulate the estimates, you can access them as we have above with fa$B and so on and so forth. Note that these are matrix and Matrix objects, and you may need to perform type coercions. We also provide some utility functions to extract estimates into tibbles:

get_varimax_z(fa)
#> # A tibble: 12 × 6
#>    id       z1    z2     z3     z4     z5
#>    <chr> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>
#>  1 row01 -4.26 -4.65 -2.19  -1.44  -0.990
#>  2 row02 -4.48 -2.26 -2.79  -1.19  -4.22 
#>  3 row03 -3.38 -4.03 -2.84  -3.15  -4.09 
#>  4 row04 -5.12 -4.13 -4.18  -1.61  -2.71 
#>  5 row05 -4.31 -4.51  0.192 -1.52  -3.26 
#>  6 row06 -4.33 -4.39 -2.48  -2.32  -3.69 
#>  7 row07 -4.37 -6.49 -2.66  -1.32  -4.08 
#>  8 row08 -1.49 -4.54 -2.29  -1.30  -3.90 
#>  9 row09 -3.45 -3.81 -2.65   0.675 -4.04 
#> 10 row10 -5.74 -4.23 -1.46  -1.25  -4.97 
#> 11 row11 -4.16 -5.35 -2.91  -2.53  -4.73 
#> 12 row12 -4.45 -5.65 -3.06   0.135 -3.98
get_varimax_y(fa)
#> # A tibble: 12 × 6
#>    id       y1     y2     y3    y4     y5
#>    <chr> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>
#>  1 col01 -4.17 -1.22   1.20  2.64   1.06 
#>  2 col02 -1.87 -1.43   1.17  3.59  -2.38 
#>  3 col03 -4.90 -1.89   1.89  3.17  -2.56 
#>  4 col04 -1.82 -1.10   1.20  1.61  -1.59 
#>  5 col05 -4.31 -0.604  2.91  2.77  -1.63 
#>  6 col06 -3.85 -2.32   3.19  1.71  -1.69 
#>  7 col07 -4.40 -1.29   0.796 0.551 -2.54 
#>  8 col08 -4.35 -1.39   0.712 4.67  -2.11 
#>  9 col09 -5.15 -1.49   0.252 2.14  -1.44 
#> 10 col10 -3.62 -1.45  -0.510 2.28  -1.32 
#> 11 col11 -4.33  1.16   1.02  2.25  -2.80 
#> 12 col12 -3.66  0.926  1.94  2.73  -0.768

To visualize a screeplot of the singular value, use:

# screeplot(fa)

At the moment, we also enjoy using pairs plots of the factors as a diagnostic measure:

# plot_varimax_z_pairs(fa, 1:3)
# plot_varimax_y_pairs(fa, 1:3)

Similarly, an IPR pairs plot can be a good way to check for singular vector localization (and thus overfitting!).

# TODO

TODO: visualizing B

TODO: selecting k

Tidygraph integration

library(tidygraph)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'tidygraph'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:igraph':
#> 
#>     groups
#> The following object is masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter

sbm <- play_blocks(25, 25, 0.1)

vsp also works on igraph and tidygraph objects:

fa2 <- vsp(sbm, rank = 5)

You can then add the resulting factor loadings back into the node information about the graph:

# if you already have a vsp object
sbm_fa2 <- sbm %>% 
  bind_varimax_z(fa2)

sbm_fa2
#> # A tbl_graph: 25 nodes and 50 edges
#> #
#> # A directed simple graph with 1 component
#> #
#> # Node Data: 25 × 6 (active)
#>   id         z1      z2     z3      z4      z5
#>   <chr>   <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
#> 1 row01  0.666  -0.392   0.384 -0.551   1.51  
#> 2 row02 -0.0445  0.575   0.169  1.35   -0.517 
#> 3 row03  0.0192  0.137   4.15  -0.102   0.0589
#> 4 row04  0.844   1.40    1.22  -0.301  -1.28  
#> 5 row05  1.01    0.0434 -0.251 -0.0912 -0.202 
#> 6 row06 -0.675   0.713   0.364 -0.922   2.03  
#> # … with 19 more rows
#> #
#> # Edge Data: 50 × 2
#>    from    to
#>   <int> <int>
#> 1     1    25
#> 2    11     2
#> 3    14     2
#> # … with 47 more rows
